content.description: Begin on Walk Up and make your way to the iron band jug at the first bolt. From here work right an up through a huge hueco to eventually reach the fourth bolt on Shotgun. Climb up to Shotgun's anchor to finish
content.location: Begin on Walk Up and end on Shotgun

content.description: Start by laying back the flake. Continue up and pull through the weakness in the overhang and continue to a narrow "S" shaped stripe. Continue laying back and move up and right to top out.
content.protection:
5 bolts + an anchor.

 NOTE: It is recommended to stick clip the first bolt.
content.location: 18ish feet to the left of Shotgun

content.description: While performing a ballet of sorts, use some creative footwork to stem and smear your way up the wide gulley. Pull on good face holds to crank through the bulge and reach the top.
content.location: First sport route to the the Barne's Overhang

content.description:
Tempura Tour Complete is the full route that extends Tempura Tour from the belay chair above Jills, moves down Poison Ivy, and traverses the rest of the way towards George's.  

  This route offers some fun exposure and is well protected, especially at the cruxes. It is a true tour of Shelter 1.
content.protection:
Total Route Gear (Well Protected): two .2's three.3's, four .4's, four .5's, three .75's, three 1's, two 2's, two 3's 

  Pitch 1: single rack .2-2 (Double .4)  

  Pitch 2: single rack .2-2 (Double 2)  

  Pitch 3: single rack .2-1 (Double .2, .75, and 1, Triple .4) 

  Pitch 4: double rack .3-3 (Triple .3, .5) (The best/crux) 

  Pitch 5: single rack .2-2 (Double .75 and 2) 

  Pitch 6: single rack .2-3 (Double 1 and 2)
content.location: Begin on the Makanda Layback, traverse all the way to George's

content.description: This is the grand traverse that lets one venture across the Shelter 1 Bluff line. This route allows you to climb high above the grassy field below and avoids the harder sections underneath the overhang. A must for anyone desiring to explore the vertical sphere of the bluff. Absolute Classic!
content.protection: Standard traditional rack, tri-cams, stoppers, slings.
content.location:
Pitch 1: Climb the Makanda Layback to the safety bolt, "give the old bolt a spin for good luck" and rig a belay backed up with a small nut.  

  Pitch 2: Traverse left through the Open Book gully and continue to the "jug chair" above Dim View and Jills. Than rig a belay. 

  Pitch 3: From here many options appear. Currently due to vegetation, most people climb straight up and finish from here, but depending on the time of year other variations may seem possible. 

  First Option: go either up or down 10-15 feet and traverse        leftward into the Poison Ivy gully. From there climb nearly to the top and traverse leftward all the way to the Chimney in the woods. From there rig a hanging belay, followed by toping out. 

  Scary Option: (5.9) From the chimney traverse all the way to Georges as a 4th pitch. John Payne had to blindly place a Friend at his feet for the only "worthy" gear.

content.description: Another high angle staircase of a climb. Easy goes it. Good first lead.
content.location: First route to the right of Right Side Route

content.description: This is a short but sweet route. Standing On Air truly begins when the featured slab of Drunkard's Crack meets the wall just left of the small wash. Climb up the face using small nubblets.
content.location: From the base of Drunkard's Crack, locate a small wash. Climb up and left of it.

content.description: Staying to the right of Camel's Hump, climb the smooth face and skip the larger holds on the left.
content.location: Refer to photo. First route to the left of Standing On Air.

content.description: Climb up the slab to reach the wide gully at the base of the crack. Pull the tricky move and enjoy casual climbing to the anchor.
content.protection: Cams .3-3 and a set of small stoppers to help protect the face.
content.location: Directly right of Easy Crack

content.description:
Climb the layback crack system through the overhang. When the crack ends, continue on small pockets while following the straightest paths. 

  Note: Not recommended without trad rehersal.
content.location: In between Walk Up and Double Barrel. Locate the short crack that goes through an overhang to the left of Shotgun. Follow a straight path up from the crack.

content.description: Begin up the ramp that leads to the Chimney. Refer to photo for specifics. Climb up the face, trick side pulls, work into the large undercling feature, then out through pockets and face holds. Stay left of the Shake N Back crack system, and right of Geroges Nose.
content.location: Refer to photo.

content.description: Climb the leftward angling crack system that juts off of the Chimney. Place cams until the angling flake feature meets the bolt line. Clip bolts from here to safely protect.
content.protection: Lead the first half with gear, as the rock quality decreases above the half way point, begin clipping bolts on the left of the crack. Follow the three bolts to an anchor.
content.location: Directly left of the Chimney. Refer to photo

content.description: Clip the bolt before pulling pulling the first bulge. Tricky is putting it mildly. Get your feet set, use the left hand side pull at the top of the seam almost directly below the first bolt. Reach up, grab the crimp with your right hand, and slap your way up the big sloper feature on the left. Climb the face and reach the bulge. Use a right handed, 2 finger pocket and perform a hard sidepull while getting your feet high to reach a decent left handed edge. Crank through and climb a short face to reach an anchor.
content.location: First sport route to the right of Tiny Dancer/first route to the left of Nowhere

content.description: High angle step climbing. Follow the water groove
content.location: First sport route to the right of Diagonal Direct

content.description: Climb through the dihedral layback leftward to the base of the gully crack.
content.protection: Standard traditional rack plus some nut placements.
content.location: Obvious gully to the middle left of the Shelter 1 bluff.

content.description: From the two stacked pockets climb through the upside down V formation and stay to the right of crackpot cave.
content.protection: 6 bolts + an anchor whichever way you chose to finish.
content.location: Starts on the two baseball sized stacked pockets about 15 feet left of Makanda Layback. Go up through the upside down V formation to the left of Open Book's bowling ball pocket.

content.description: Pull through the short moderate boulder problem to the base of the gully crack, mantle into the gully and enjoy.
content.protection: Standard trad rack plus nut placements
content.location: Directly under the gully crack.

content.description:
Begin at the base of the Makanda Layback, climb up and left to the bowling ball pocket, climb out through the Open Book gully. 

Variation: Begin by climbing through the gully of Makanda Layback after climbing through its gully, traverse left into the open book formation and go up it.
content.location: Base of the Makanda Layback

content.description: Begin with the short, overhung start. Pull up and stand on iron-band ledge. Pull up and to the "pentagonal" hand pocket. Continue up the slab to a 3-finger pocket. Pull the move and follow good holds to the finish.
content.location: First sport route to the left of Joe's Variation

content.description: Beginning on Double Barrel, climb up and only use the left of the large hueco's that make the "double barrel". Basically continue to the top from here. This is an eliminate version of Double Barrel.
content.location: Shares the same start as Double Barrel

climbs.name: My Feet Are Smiling
climbs.fa: Doug Drewes & Joe Healy circa 1970's. Leo Kottke fans

content.description:
PLEASE NOTE: If unfamiliar with the route, it is recommended to stick clip the first bolt.  

  Beginning on Graves, head up and right to a 2 foot "peanut" shaped hueco. From there work left for about a move, then back right and up through a honeycomb section into the cave of Crackpot. Work out and up the face to the anchor.
content.location: Shares the same start as Graves.

content.description: Climb over the small hump using a few ticks moves. Work up the apex of that feature and continue to the top.
content.location: To the right of the Makanda Layback and left of The Gully.

content.description: Pull on small jugs to enter the gully crack, layback to the right and pull moves to eventually reach up left to nice horizontal edges, from there proceed to climb to the safety bolt "place a nut in the crack to the right to beef up the anchor point", then continue to the top through a rather blank section eventually meeting the last face, angle up and left eventually toping out and reaching the anchor. Fairly Committing Lead...
content.protection: Smaller trad gear down low then work into 5 bolts + anchor
content.location: gully crack to the left of the camels hump

content.description: This climb is similar to Drunkards in the way of how it angles to the right and is well protected. This is a great climb for those learning trad. Crux is either the crux of Makanda Layback or getting off the ground for The Gully
content.location: Begin at the base of Makanda Layback, climb up to the bolt, clip in and follow the crack at your feet as it angles to the right, top out on  Camel's Hump and use the anchors to belay partners up. (Easier Variation: climb up The Gully, go to the bolt, and then traverse right)

content.description: Originally, you were to ascend the left facing crack system continuing straight above. Now, you begin just right of the original crack and climb the face.
content.location: A few feet left of The Bulge, refer to photo for specifics.

content.description:
PLEASE NOTE: Jill's is difficult from the start. If you are not sure about the gear either stick clip or rappel down from the three eye bolts placed on top of the bluff and preplace you gear before attempting. This route is extremely fun, but unless you know the gear, you may be running serious risk.  

  Send the leftward leaning dihedral crack using pocketed holds on the left for feet "kinda hard to place gear", climb over the first bulge and look for gear placements, continue straight up looking for traditional placements, climb past the jug chair and reach the top for a good place to clip in.
content.protection:
Stick Clip The First Bolt.  

  5 bolts + an anchor
content.location: It's the obvious leftward leaning zig-zagging crack to the right of Poison Ivy.

content.description:
Beginning on Graves, climb up and left about 4 feet. continue directly up and avoid Grave's horizontal hand slot. Top out through the overhang of Dim View. 

 Note, this is a top rope variation.
content.location: Begin on Graves, refer to photo

content.description: Starting just to the right of the tree, climb up for about 20 feet. Then continue up and right for 30 more feet, crossing back onto Dead Dog.  Continue by climbing through iron bands and finish by Cedar tree.
content.location: Start about 8 feet left of Dead Dog. Refer to photo.

content.description: Beginning with a unique high stepping mantle, balance over on your feet using shallow divots. Layback, high step, and slab climb your way to the anchor.
content.location: About 10 feet to the right of Standing On Air

content.description: Beginning a few feet left of Joe's. Locate the large pinch hold and crank up the face. Use a series of side pulls, edges, and underclings to reach the bulge. Reach out right, stick the pocket and work your way over the bulge using pockets and a life saving edge. Easier moves to the anchor from here.
content.location: Begins a few feet left of Joe's Variation, refer to photo for specifics.

content.description: Either choose to move a picnic table to the juggy ledge to aid in starting the route, or begin directly under the Camel's Hump and traverse left into the gully. Either way, stay left of Camel's Hump and work up through the slab towards jugs.
content.location: Its the wash left of Camel's Back

climbs.name: Graves
climbs.fa: Joe Healy, Doug Drewes, Adam Grosowsky

content.description:
PLEASE NOTE: If unfamiliar with the beginning sequence, it is highly recommended to stick clip the first bolt.  

  (Pronounced GROVZ) "not recommended to be led without rehearsal" With small cave located climb through pockets, face holds, and side pulls to eventually reach the infamous cave of Graves, from there traverse left until you reach the small gully above the main crack of Jill's, plug and chug your way to the "jug chair", clip the old safety piece and top out.
content.location: Locate the small cave in-between Jill's and Crackpot, climb through holds directly below it, and top out above Jill's

content.description:
Start on George's Direct but avoid the gully/crack system. Continue stright up, pulling directly throught the "nose" on the right side of the gully/crack. Follow path of least resistance. 

  Note: not recommended without trad rehersal.
content.location: Refer to photo. Begins to the right of George's

content.description: Start directly below on the right side and make you way towards the chimney, plug your way through the gully crack.
content.protection: You can clip three bolts as you climb up the face, then use catalogs 1-3 to protect crack, and now has a bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: The next large gully crack to the left of Chimney.

content.description: This is the no-hands version of Drunkards Crack.
content.protection: If I recall correctly the last high step off the top is R/Xish as you really have to lean forward and commit or you'll for sure launch off and go flying backwards off the damn thing.
content.location: It started a bit to the left (to the right of the direct start to Camels Back), but I suspect by now the ground under the original start has probably long since eroded away making what was an already a super challenging, if not utterly desperate, sticking of the first move all but impossible (improvise).

content.description: Begin at the base of Makanda Layback and climb up and left of M.L. setting yourself to climb up through the blank face
content.location: Start on Makanda Layback, angle leftward and ascend the blank face. Stay left of the crack on Makanda Layback and right of Open Book's bowling ball pocket.

content.description: Climb the slabby face finding good holds along the way, then when the face goes vertical, stay right of the crack feature. This route shares anchors with Easy Crack. Note: once you have this route set up, take a fun top rope lap on Easy Crack.
content.location: Farthest left bolted route on the wall. Directly left of Barnes Overhang.

content.description:
Climb through the fractured crack system, eventually working you way through the pocketed upper face to the anchor.  

  Note: make sure you find the horizontal gear placement before leaving the wide upper crack.
content.location: This is the obvious crack up the hill and left of George's. Refer to photo.

content.description: Climb Dim View on trad gear. Boulder through crux sequence about 20 ft to good stance and some good but small gear( .75 and blue or purple Metolius TCU). Pull through the next pumpy sequence to reach another break which will take a #1 or #2 BD Cam.   Climb through the upper crux, sling the horn if you'd like then on to the anchors.
content.protection: C4's- .75, 1, 2.   Metolius TCU- Blue or Purple   Slings

content.description: Its the obvious wide crack that leads to the top. Commonly soloed to set more difficult routes. Great route for teaching traditional placements.
content.protection: Single rack and an anchor at the top.
content.location: Located on the far right of shelter 1 bluff. It is the obvious rightward leaning crack. Two smaller trees are rooted in the crack in the lower section. Refer to photo.

content.description:
After locating to two large pockets (the end of the double barrel), climb up following the straightest path. One of the more contiguous vertical routes on the bluff. 

  Note: gear placements are limited in the lower section, but improve as you continue higher. Not recommended without trad rehersal.
content.protection: Standard traditional rack, tri-cams, nuts, alpine draws
content.location: Begin on Poison Ivy Left and continue straight up through two large pockets while avoiding the gully.

climbs.name: Dim View
climbs.fa: Doug Drews, Joe Healy, Jim Foster 1970's

content.description:
PLEASE NOTE: If unfamiliar, it is recommended to stick clip the first bolt. Dim View is not as straight forward as it may seem. Also, due to the span between bolts 1 and 2, make sure your belayer is on their "A Game", to keep you off the ground if a fall were to occur.  

  Start on the small boulder in the ground for Return To Forever, from there climb up and left, when you reach the first big horizontal go straight up from there, eventually pulling through the jug chair, pick the path of least resistance to top out to Jill's anchor.
content.location: Locate the small boulder in the ground that is used to start Return To Forever, from there climb up and left while paralleling Jill's

content.description: Climb the sloping face and work your way to the anchor of Drunkard's Crack.
content.location: Face directly right of Drunkard's Crack

content.description: Climb to the small cave feature then work through the overhung crack feature until it ends. Step up on a slabby face and work through face holds and pockets and eventually reach the anchor.
content.location: A few feet left of Walk Up. Refer to Photo.

climbs.name: Crackpot
climbs.fa: Jim Foster (during snowfall) 1970's, first free lead Chris Ecklund with worthless gear 1988

content.description: Climb the overhanging crack system into the little cave straight above, continue above it and top out.
content.location: Locate the cave about midway up and left of the Open Book Gully, follow the crack system leading up to it and top out.

content.description:
Layback the crack that comes out of the right side of the cave feature. Follow the first crack system until a horizontal, iron-banded ledge, clip the bolt and traverse right into the other crack system. Follow the crack and place gear as you climb. NOTE! As you near the end of the crack, excellent horizontal gear placements emerge. Pull the face moved under the upper bulge of the climb and clip a bolt. Face moves up and right lead to the anchor.

 Note: this is an excellent route that leads very well with gear. Bolts are exactly where you need them.
content.protection:
NOTE: It is highly recommended to stick clip the first bolt!

 2 bolts, cams No. .5-3 (doubles in No. 1 & 2), + an anchor
content.location: The route begins on the small crack on the leftside of the small cave to the left of Shotgun.

content.description:
One of the first 5.12's in the country. Starting on good holds, climb the overhanging pocketed face. Rest on the slab about midway up, then pull your way up the next overhang. The pocket pulling was futuristic for its time. 

  The initial crux has been soloed by Adam Grosowsky, Alan Carrier, and Jim Thurmond. Also has been led by Jim Thurmond through the upper section overhang in the late 1980's
content.protection:
Stick Clip The First Bolt! 

  4 bolts + anchor
content.location: Nestled between Jill's and Poison Ivy Right, climb through the pocketed face while avoiding both crack systems.

content.description: Start at the bottom left, follow the crack up to the chimney, pull through the chimney.
content.protection: Standard traditional rack primarily on the larger side. There is now a bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: First large chimney in the woods left of Poison Ivy.

content.description: Start up Crackpot until you get to third bolt then cut left all the way to City Limits. You will pass through the cave on Graves on the way. Keep traversing until you reach the rest after City Limits crux. Finish the upper wall on City Limits. Long draw on the third bolt of crackpot eliminates any rope drag.
content.location: Start on Crackpot

content.description: This popular TR goes up the huge hump in the wall. By placing a picnic table at the base of the climb, you can make the start easier. Begin at the bottom-right of the hump and climb up toward the center. Top out through vertical bucket climbing. According to the 1972 guide Sandstone Climber, "every inch of the Camels Hump has been climbed."
content.location: Goes up the huge hump in the wall to the left of Drunkard's Crack.

content.description: Start on the short rightward tieback. Pull the mantel shelf about 10 feet up. Then go straight up to the top while staying 6 feet left of George's chimney.
content.location: Starts a few feet left of George's direct, refer to the photo for specifics.

content.description: Work your way up the slab and through pocketed holds in the overhang.
content.location: First route to the right of Easy Crack. Refer to photo

climbs.name: Anchors Away AKA Enchained Melody
climbs.fa: May 9, 2020. Andrew Staff and Dave Hug

content.description: This route traverses almost the entire length of the cliff. From the anchors of "Drunkards Crack" all the way across the bluff to the anchors of "Easy Crack". The climbing isn't that difficult, there are some tricky down climbing sections as well as a couple of run out spots. It's a fun way to get some easy mileage in and to touch some holds you probably haven't touched before. I belayed the second at the anchors for Gráves and the anchors for The Chimney.

Extremely featured great quality sandstone. A truly unique climbing experience. This is the home of progressive climbing in Illinois. Come climb these historic routes and share in these classic test pieces.
